item.title: US Regulators Seek Rollback of 1-Minute Bond Trade Reporting
item.description: US financial regulators want to roll back measures introduced during the Biden administration that slashed some fixed-income trade reporting to just one minute, calling to return to the 15-minute status quo for disclosing many bond transactions.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Beyoud

media:content.media:description: The US Securities and Exchange Commission headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: Wealthsimple CEO Michael Katchen Says IPO Remains Goal as Assets Top $50 Billion
item.description: The head of celebrity-backed Wealthsimple Financial Corp. says there’s no need to rush into an initial public offering as the fintech sees a surge in client assets.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Hughes

media:content.media:description: Mike Katchen, chief executive officer of Wealthsimple Inc., smiles during an interview in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2019. Within five years, Wealthsimple has attracted 150,000 customers in Canada, the U.S. and U.K., and now manages more than C$4.5 billion ($3.4 billion).

item.title: What Another Month of Cooling CPI Actually Means
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Avocados from Mexico at a grocery store in New York, US, on Wednesday, Feb. 12, 2025. US inflation rose broadly at the start of the year, led by increases in household expenses like groceries, gas, and housing costs. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

item.title: European Gas Rises Amid Warm Weather as Trump Sees US-China Deal
item.description: European natural gas prices gained on forecasts of above-normal temperatures across the continent and as US President Donald Trump said a trade deal with China had been reached.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya, Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: Air conditioning units in Barcelona. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Europe Set to Reaffirm Plan to Pressure Russia Despite US Delays
item.description: Europe will reiterate its commitment to back Ukraine and sanction Russia, as the US delays a decision over increasing pressure on Moscow to get President Vladimir Putin to the negotiating table.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini

media:content.media:description: Women stand near a damaged residential building following a Russian drone strike in Kharkiv, on June 11.

item.title: US Stocks Waffle as Traders Weigh US-China Trade Progress
item.description: US stocks shuffled between small gains and losses Wednesday afternoon, as traders looked past an upbeat report on cooling consumer prices and assessed the outlook for global trade.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. Risk appetites vanished on Wall Street after the biggest burst of buying in years, with stocks falling even after subdued inflation data extended a bounce in Treasuries.

item.title: Brookfield Names Baron CEO of Real Estate Group Amid Shakeup
item.description: Brookfield Asset Management tapped 20-year veteran Lowell Baron as the new chief executive officer of its real estate business, as one of the world’s biggest property owners reshuffles the leadership of that unit.
item.dc:creator: Jack Sidders, Layan Odeh

media:content.media:description: Brookfield Asset Management headquarters in New York.

item.title: Bond Yields Fall as Tame Inflation Fuels Fed Bets: Markets Wrap
item.description: A fourth month of surprisingly benign US inflation drove bond yields down, with Wall Street investors seeing greater leeway for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates should trade frictions slow the economy. The dollar retreated. Stocks fluctuated.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth, Andre Janse Van Vuuren

item.title: Auto-Parts Supplier Marelli Files Bankruptcy, Blames Tariffs
item.description: Marelli Holdings Co., the long struggling auto-parts supplier for Nissan Motor Co., Stellantis NV and other carmakers, filed bankruptcy in the US, saying its latest debt-cutting effort was prompted by tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Reed Stevenson, Giulia Morpurgo, Dorothy Ma

media:content.media:description: The Marelli Corp. headquarters in Saitama, Japan.

item.title: Polish Fiscal Risks Cast Shadow Over Tusk’s Renewed Mandate
item.description: Poland’s Prime Minister Donald Tusk failed to dispel doubts about his weakened government’s agenda despite winning a parliamentary vote of confidence in his cabinet.
item.dc:creator: Wojciech Moskwa, Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: The Palace of Science and Culture on the city skyline in Warsaw, Poland.

item.title: Paul Tudor Jones Sees Bessent as Trump Pick for Fed Chair
item.description: Paul Tudor Jones said President Donald Trump is likely to appoint an “uber dovish” Federal Reserve chair to accommodate his growth agenda, contending that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent would likely be his pick when Jerome Powell’s term ends next year.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Cantrell, Katie Greifeld, Matthew Miller

media:content.media:description: Paul Tudor Jones

item.title: UK Navy Issues Rare Warning to Ships Near Vital Hormuz Strait
item.description: The UK Navy issued a rare warning to mariners that higher tensions in the Middle East could impact shipping, including through the Strait of Hormuz.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Two oil tankers are seen at a distance in the waters of Strait of Hormuz in Hormuz Island, Iran.

item.title: Oil Rallies as Trump Doubts Iran Talks, Sees China Deal ‘Done’
item.description: Oil prices rallied as US President Donald Trump signaled skepticism over talks with Iran and confidence in a trade deal with China.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Liberty Lift Solutions LLC pumpjacks near Crane, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch. Photographer: Justin Hamel/Bloomberg

item.title: NJ Transit Engineers Union Votes in Favor of New Wage Pact
item.description: New Jersey Transit’s locomotive engineers ratified the new wage contract which was the result of an agreement following a three-day strike that halted rail service in May.
item.dc:creator: Sri Taylor

media:content.media:description: Members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen picket outside of the Hoboken Terminal during a strike in Hoboken, New Jersey, US, on Friday, May 16, 2025. New Jersey Transit locomotive engineers started striking early Friday, triggering a shutdown of the agency's rail service and disrupting travel for thousands of commuters.

item.title: Spain’s Grid Denies Report It Mishandled Voltage Before Blackout
item.description: Spanish grid operator Red Electrica denies it took any action that was out of the ordinary in the minutes before a blackout hit the country on April 28.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians try to use their mobile phones on an unlit street during a power outage in Molins de Rei, Spain, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Spain and Portugal lost power shortly after 12:30 p.m. local time in a massive blackout that idled public transport, airports and phone services, bringing the daily activities of millions to a halt.

item.title: Trump Says China Will Ship Rare Earths in ‘Done’ Trade Deal
item.description: President Donald Trump said a trade framework with China has been completed, with Beijing supplying rare earths and magnets “UP FRONT” and the US allowing Chinese students into its colleges and universities.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Skylar Woodhouse

item.title: Bessent Predicts US Budget Deficit Nearing 7% This Year
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the US is suffering from “the biggest blow out for the deficit in history,” and blamed Democrats for the current tax year budget deficit coming in between 6.5% and 6.7%. Bessent spoke during an exchange with Rep. Richard Neal, a Democrat from Massachusetts, before the House Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday.

item.title: Will French Nuclear Woes Return as EDF Find Hints of New Cracks in Reactor Pipes?
item.description: Electricite de France SA has found indications that “stress corrosion” cracks may have returned to pipes at a nuclear reactor fixed less than three years ago, renewing fears about the reliability of the country’s power supply.
item.dc:creator: Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: The cooling towers of the nuclear power plant in Civaux, France.

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 6/11/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Payment Company Stripe to Acquire Crypto Wallet Provider Privy
item.description: Stripe Inc. agreed to acquire crypto wallet provider Privy, building on the payment company’s recent acquisition of stablecoin infrastructure firm Bridge.
item.dc:creator: Emily Mason

media:content.media:description: The Stripe Inc. headquarters in South San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, April 16, 2024. Stripe, the fintech that helps merchants process customer payments, said in March that volume surged 25% last year to more than $1 trillion. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Here Are the Winners and Losers of UK’s Big Spending Shake-Up
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves laid out how she’ll divide more than £600 billion ($810 billion) of annual spending between departments, capping Labour’s first year in power. The decisions will have a broad impact across the UK, where the outlays account for about a fifth of the economy.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, outside 11 Downing Street ahead of the presentation of the spending review in London, on June 11.

item.title: Bessent Credits Trump Policies for Inflation Slowdown
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent credited President Donald Trump’s policies for a “substantial improvement” in US inflation during testimony Wednesday before the House Ways and Means Committee.

item.title: ‘Difficult’ to See Brazil Upswing Before 2026 Vote, Moody’s Says
item.description: Brazil’s government didn’t do enough to improve its credibility with investors, pushing the central bank to hike interest rates more than expected and making it “difficult” to see improvements before 2026 elections, according to Moody’s Ratings’ Samar Maziad.
item.dc:creator: Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Brazil’s president, at a ceremony in Paris, France, on June 5, 2025.

item.title: Tudor Jones on Next Fed Chair, Trump Budget, Markets
item.description: Paul Tudor Jones, founder of Tudor Investment Corp., says President Donald Trump will probably appoint an "uber dovish" Federal Reserve Chair to replace Jerome Powell. He also talks about where he thinks interest rates will wind up, Trump's proposed budget, and artificial intelligence. He speaks on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Rises on Bets of Fed Interest Rate Cuts; Platinum Surges
item.description: Gold rose after a softer-than-expected inflation reading bolstered bets that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates later this year.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Sybilla Gross, Yvonne Yue Li

item.title: Bloomberg's Global Credit Forum Kicks Off in LA

media:content.media:description: Downtown Los Angeles skyline. Photographer: Kyle Grillot/Bloomberg

item.title: AI Bets That Fueled Big Tech’s Surge Now Threaten Rich Profits
item.description: Some investors are questioning the amount of cash Big Tech is throwing at artificial intelligence, fueling concerns for profit margins and the risk that depreciation expenses will drag stocks down before companies can see investments pay off.
item.dc:creator: Jeran Wittenstein

item.title: UniCredit’s Orcel Rules Out Commerzbank Bid at Current Price
item.description: UniCredit SpA Chief Executive Officer Andrea Orcel effectively ruled out making an offer for Commerzbank AG at the current price, saying such a move wouldn’t add value after a rally in the stock.
item.dc:creator: Sonia Sirletti, Antonio Vanuzzo

media:content.media:description: Andrea Orcel Photographer: Francesca Volpi/Bloomberg

item.title: Tudor Jones Says Next Fed Chair Should Be 'Uber Dovish'
item.description: Billionaire investor Paul Tudor Jones said President Donald Trump is likely to appoint an “uber dovish” Federal Reserve chair to accommodate his growth agenda, adding he thinks US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent would be his likely pick when Jerome Powell’s term ends. Jones speaks on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Treasuries Rally as Soft Inflation Fuels Bets on Fed Rate Cuts
item.description: Treasuries surged as easing US consumer inflation prompted traders to increase wagers on more than one Federal Reserve interest-rate cut this year.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie
